description: Expanded mappings for 50 additional careers to curriculum topics

new_mappings.real_world_application: Nurses calculate medication dosages daily based on patient weight and condition. Incorrect calculations can be life-threatening.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Patient weighs 60kg. Doctor prescribes 5mg per kg of medication. Nurse calculates: 60kg × 5mg = 300mg total dosage needed.
new_mappings.required_for: Medication administration, IV drip calculations, dosage conversions, patient monitoring

new_mappings.real_world_application: Nurses measure vital signs (temperature, blood pressure, pulse) and must record them accurately using proper units.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Taking temperature: Normal = 37°C. Patient shows 39.5°C = fever. Pulse: 72 beats per minute = normal. Blood pressure: 120/80 mmHg = normal.
new_mappings.required_for: Patient assessment, vital signs monitoring, medication measurements, health tracking

new_mappings.real_world_application: Understanding living organisms is fundamental to medicine - knowing how cells, organs, and body systems function to maintain life.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Diagnosing infection: Identifying living microorganisms (bacteria, viruses) invading the body and prescribing treatment to eliminate them while keeping patient's cells healthy.
new_mappings.required_for: Disease diagnosis, understanding human biology, identifying pathogens, treatment planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Doctors calculate precise drug dosages, interpret lab values, and determine treatment durations using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Child with malaria: Weight 25kg, needs 10mg/kg chloroquine. Calculation: 25 × 10 = 250mg total dose, divided into 3 days = 250 ÷ 3 ≈ 83mg per day.
new_mappings.required_for: Drug prescription, dosage calculation, interpreting test results, treatment planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Pharmacists work with medications in different states (solid pills, liquid syrups, gas inhalers) and must understand their properties for proper storage and dispensing.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Liquid medicines must be shaken before use because particles settle. Inhalers contain gas under pressure. Storing medications: solids in cool dry place, liquids away from heat, gases in pressurized containers.
new_mappings.required_for: Medication preparation, proper storage, understanding drug forms, compounding prescriptions

new_mappings.real_world_application: Medication dosages use fractions and decimals constantly. Pharmacists must convert between forms and calculate precise amounts.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Prescription: 0.5mg tablet, but only 1mg tablets available. Pharmacist instructs: Cut tablet in half (1 ÷ 2 = 0.5). Or: Take 1/4 teaspoon = 0.25 teaspoon.
new_mappings.required_for: Dosage calculations, prescription preparation, unit conversions, compounding medications

new_mappings.real_world_application: Lab work IS the scientific method - observe samples, form hypotheses about diseases, test through experiments, record precise measurements.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Blood test: Observe sample color/appearance → Measure hemoglobin level (12.5 g/dL) → Compare to normal range (12-16) → Conclude: within normal limits. Record all data accurately.
new_mappings.required_for: Conducting tests, recording results, quality control, diagnosis support

new_mappings.real_world_application: X-rays, CT scans, and MRIs all use different forms of energy (electromagnetic radiation, magnetic fields) to create images of the body.
new_mappings.example_scenario: X-ray machine converts electrical energy → electromagnetic radiation (X-rays) that passes through soft tissue but is blocked by bones, creating shadow images on detector.
new_mappings.required_for: Operating imaging equipment, understanding radiation safety, adjusting exposure settings, image quality

new_mappings.real_world_application: Radiographers calculate radiation exposure doses, image magnification ratios, and patient positioning measurements.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Calculate radiation dose: Patient weight 70kg × 0.5 mSv per kg = 35 mSv total exposure. Image magnification: 10cm on screen ÷ 2cm actual = 5× magnification.
new_mappings.required_for: Radiation dosage, safety calculations, image sizing, positioning accuracy

new_mappings.real_world_application: Every algorithm uses multiplication and division - calculating loops, processing arrays, optimizing performance, managing memory.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Processing 1,000,000 records at 100 per second: 1,000,000 ÷ 100 = 10,000 seconds = 166.7 minutes = 2.8 hours to complete. Grid layout: 100 items in 10 rows = 100 ÷ 10 = 10 items per row.
new_mappings.required_for: Algorithm design, performance optimization, data processing, UI layouts

new_mappings.real_world_application: Developers use ratios for responsive design, scaling images, calculating percentages, and managing resources.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Responsive design: Desktop screen 1920 pixels, mobile 480 pixels. Ratio 1920:480 = 4:1. Elements must scale proportionally. Image 400px wide on desktop = 400 ÷ 4 = 100px on mobile.
new_mappings.required_for: UI/UX design, resource allocation, performance scaling, data visualization

new_mappings.real_world_application: Understanding text formatting, fonts, and document structure is foundation for HTML/CSS and web page styling.
new_mappings.example_scenario:
HTML is like word processing:

= Heading 1 (largest),

= paragraph, = bold, = italic. CSS styles text just like formatting toolbar: color, size, font family.
new_mappings.required_for: HTML structure, CSS styling, text content management, web page layout

new_mappings.real_world_application: Data analysis is built on calculating averages (division), growth rates (multiplication), and statistical measures.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Sales analysis: Total sales GHS 500,000 ÷ 50 sales reps = GHS 10,000 average per rep. Growth: This year 500,000, last year 400,000. Increase = 500 ÷ 400 = 1.25 = 25% growth.
new_mappings.required_for: Calculating averages, percentages, trends, statistical analysis, performance metrics

new_mappings.real_world_application: Spreadsheets (Excel) are the PRIMARY tool for data analysis. Data analysts spend most of their time in Excel analyzing data.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Using Excel formulas: =SUM() to total sales, =AVERAGE() for mean values, =IF() for conditional analysis, pivot tables to summarize thousands of rows into insights.
new_mappings.required_for: Data manipulation, statistical analysis, creating visualizations, reporting findings

new_mappings.real_world_application: Fashion designers calculate fabric requirements, pattern scaling, and garment pricing using multiplication and division constantly.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Dress needs 3.5 meters of fabric. Making 12 dresses: 3.5 × 12 = 42 meters total. Fabric costs GHS 15 per meter: 42 × 15 = GHS 630. Selling price must cover costs plus profit.
new_mappings.required_for: Material estimation, cost calculation, pattern sizing, production planning

new_mappings.topic_name: Numbers and Numeration (Place Value, Large Numbers)
new_mappings.real_world_application: Tailors take precise body measurements in centimeters and must read measuring tapes accurately to ensure proper fit.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Client measurements: Chest 96cm, Waist 78cm, Hip 102cm, Length 145cm. Must read each value precisely - 96 is very different from 69! Recording: Hip 102.5cm means 102 plus 0.5 = exactly between 102 and 103.
new_mappings.required_for: Taking accurate measurements, cutting fabric precisely, ensuring garment fit, pricing materials

new_mappings.real_world_application: Journalists interview people from all professions and must understand their work to report accurately on economic, social, and political issues.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Writing story on unemployment: Must understand different job sectors - formal vs informal, agricultural vs industrial workers, skilled vs unskilled labor - to report economic trends accurately.
new_mappings.required_for: Research and reporting, interviewing professionals, understanding economic issues, contextualizing news

new_mappings.real_world_application: Camera settings use fractions (shutter speed 1/250, aperture f/2.8) and photographers must understand these to control exposure and image quality.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Shutter speed 1/500 = very fast, freezes motion. 1/30 = slower, may blur. Aperture f/2.8 = large opening (2.8 parts), shallow depth. f/16 = small opening (16 parts), everything in focus.
new_mappings.required_for: Camera settings, exposure control, lighting calculations, print sizing

new_mappings.real_world_application: Agronomy is about understanding how living plants interact with non-living soil, water, sunlight to produce food.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Soil analysis: Non-living components (minerals, water, air, pH) support living components (plants, beneficial microorganisms). Healthy soil = right balance. Adding fertilizer (non-living nutrients) helps plants (living) grow.
new_mappings.required_for: Crop production, soil management, pest control, plant health assessment

new_mappings.real_world_application: Agronomists calculate fertilizer rates, seed spacing, crop yields, and field areas using multiplication and division daily.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Field is 50m × 40m = 2,000 square meters. Fertilizer rate: 100kg per 1,000m². For 2,000m²: (2,000 ÷ 1,000) × 100 = 200kg needed. Maize spacing: 30 plants per row, 20 rows = 30 × 20 = 600 plants total.
new_mappings.required_for: Fertilizer calculations, yield estimation, field planning, resource management

new_mappings.real_world_application: Livestock managers calculate feed requirements, medication dosages, and production outputs for hundreds of animals daily.
new_mappings.example_scenario: 100 chickens eat 50kg feed per day. For 30 days: 50 × 30 = 1,500kg feed needed. Each chicken produces 0.8 eggs/day: 100 × 0.8 = 80 eggs daily. Monthly: 80 × 30 = 2,400 eggs.
new_mappings.required_for: Feed budgeting, medication dosing, production tracking, financial planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Food processing involves changing states of matter - freezing, melting, boiling, drying - to preserve food and create products.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Ice cream: Liquid milk + sugar → freeze to solid. Juice concentrate: Liquid juice → heat to evaporate water → thick concentrate. Freeze-dried foods: Frozen → directly to gas (sublimation), removing water while keeping structure.
new_mappings.required_for: Food preservation, product development, quality control, processing techniques

new_mappings.real_world_application: Teachers calculate grades, attendance percentages, class averages, and resource allocation using addition and subtraction.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Class of 40 students. Present today: 37. Absent: 40 - 37 = 3. Test scores: 85 + 78 + 92 + 88 = 343. Average: 343 ÷ 4 = 85.75. Class average: Sum all 40 scores, divide by 40.
new_mappings.required_for: Grading, attendance tracking, class statistics, resource planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Lawyers must understand various professions to handle cases in employment law, professional negligence, and workplace disputes.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Employment dispute case: Must understand duties of the profession in question. What does a nurse's job entail? What are reasonable expectations for a driver? Professional standards vary by occupation.
new_mappings.required_for: Case preparation, understanding professional standards, employment law, expert witnesses

new_mappings.real_world_application: Police must know community resources - hospitals, schools, emergency services - to protect citizens and respond effectively to incidents.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Emergency call: Lost child. Officer must know: nearby schools (where child might attend), community leaders (who can help), safe houses (where to take child), social services (follow-up support).
new_mappings.required_for: Community policing, emergency response, resource coordination, crime prevention

new_mappings.real_world_application: Firefighting is ALL about states of matter - liquid water turns fires (solid/gas) back to safe states, understanding smoke (gas) behavior saves lives.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Water (liquid) absorbs heat from fire, turning to steam (gas) which removes oxygen. Smoke (gas particles) rises - stay low to breathe. Ice on roads (solid) makes rescue dangerous. Chemical fires need special suppressants.
new_mappings.required_for: Fire suppression, safety protocols, rescue operations, hazard assessment

new_mappings.real_world_application: International trade requires calculating customs duties, exchange rates, shipping costs, and profit margins on cross-border transactions.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Import cost: $1,000 goods at 6 cedis per dollar = GHS 6,000. Customs duty 20% = GHS 1,200. Shipping GHS 500. Total cost = 6,000 + 1,200 + 500 = GHS 7,700. Must sell above this for profit.
new_mappings.required_for: Import costing, duty calculation, currency exchange, profit planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Insurance is pure financial calculation - premiums, coverage amounts, deductibles, and claim payouts all require precise math.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Car insurance: Car value GHS 50,000. Premium 5% annually = 50,000 × 0.05 = GHS 2,500/year. Accident claim: Damage GHS 10,000, deductible GHS 2,000. Insurance pays: 10,000 - 2,000 = GHS 8,000.
new_mappings.required_for: Premium calculation, policy pricing, claims processing, risk assessment

new_mappings.real_world_application: Auditing is verifying that additions and subtractions in financial records are correct - checking every calculation in a company's books.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Auditing cash book: Opening balance GHS 10,000 + Income GHS 50,000 - Expenses GHS 35,000 = GHS 25,000 closing. If actual cash is GHS 24,500, there's GHS 500 discrepancy to investigate.
new_mappings.required_for: Financial verification, error detection, compliance checking, fraud investigation

new_mappings.real_world_application: Surveyors calculate land areas, distances, and elevations using multiplication and division to create accurate property boundaries.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Rectangular plot: 50m × 30m = 1,500 square meters. Converting to acres: 1,500 ÷ 4,047 (m² per acre) = 0.37 acres. Slope calculation: Vertical rise 5m ÷ horizontal distance 100m = 5% slope.
new_mappings.required_for: Area calculation, boundary determination, mapping, elevation surveying

new_mappings.real_world_application: Surveyors create precise technical drawings showing property boundaries, topography, and land features using drawing instruments.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Survey map at 1:500 scale. A 100m boundary line is drawn as 100 ÷ 500 = 0.2m = 20cm on paper. All measurements must be proportionally accurate for legal property documents.
new_mappings.required_for: Map creation, boundary documentation, legal surveys, property records

new_mappings.real_world_application: Interior designers calculate room areas, material quantities, furniture spacing, and project costs using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Living room: 6m × 5m = 30m². Flooring tiles: Each tile covers 0.5m². Tiles needed: 30 ÷ 0.5 = 60 tiles. Add 10% for waste: 60 × 1.1 = 66 tiles. Cost: 66 × GHS 15 = GHS 990.
new_mappings.required_for: Space planning, material estimation, budget calculation, furniture layout

new_mappings.real_world_application: Plumbers calculate pipe lengths, water flow rates, tank capacities, and job costs using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Water tank: 2m × 1.5m × 1m = 3 cubic meters = 3,000 liters capacity. Pipe needed: 15 meters at GHS 20/meter = 15 × 20 = GHS 300. Flow rate: 120 liters per 10 minutes = 120 ÷ 10 = 12 liters/minute.
new_mappings.required_for: Material estimation, capacity calculations, pricing jobs, system design

new_mappings.real_world_application: Welders calculate metal lengths, angles, material costs, and welding time using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Steel gate needs 8 vertical bars at 2m each + 5 horizontal bars at 1.5m each. Total length: (8 × 2) + (5 × 1.5) = 16 + 7.5 = 23.5 meters. At GHS 15/meter = 23.5 × 15 = GHS 352.50.
new_mappings.required_for: Material calculation, cost estimation, joint measurements, project planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Carpenters must understand different wood types and their properties to select the right material for each project - strength, durability, workability.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Door frame: Use hardwood (mahogany, teak) - strong, doesn't warp, durable. Ceiling boards: Softwood (pine) - lighter, easier to work, cheaper. Outdoor furniture: Treated wood - resists water and insects.
new_mappings.required_for: Material selection, quality work, project durability, cost-effective building

new_mappings.real_world_application: Masons calculate blocks needed, mortar quantities, and wall areas using multiplication and division on every construction project.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Wall: 10m long × 3m high = 30m² area. Standard block = 0.45m × 0.225m = 0.10125m². Blocks needed: 30 ÷ 0.10125 = 296 blocks. Add 5% for breakage: 296 × 1.05 = 311 blocks.
new_mappings.required_for: Material estimation, wall building, cost calculation, project planning

new_mappings.real_world_application: Hair coloring uses precise ratios and measurements - mixing dyes, developer ratios, processing times all require understanding fractions.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Hair dye mixing: 1 part color + 1.5 parts developer. For full head: 60ml color + (60 × 1.5) = 60 + 90 = 150ml total mixture. Processing time: 0.5 hour = 30 minutes.
new_mappings.required_for: Chemical mixing, coloring services, pricing calculations, product inventory

new_mappings.real_world_application: Cooking recipes use fractions constantly - 1/2 cup flour, 1/4 teaspoon salt, 2.5 kg meat. Chefs scale recipes up or down daily.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Recipe serves 4 people, need to serve 10. Scale factor: 10 ÷ 4 = 2.5. Every ingredient × 2.5: 2 cups flour becomes 2 × 2.5 = 5 cups. 1/4 tsp salt becomes 1/4 × 2.5 = 0.625 tsp.
new_mappings.required_for: Recipe scaling, portioning, cost calculation, ingredient measurement

new_mappings.real_world_application: Hotel managers calculate occupancy rates, staff-to-guest ratios, and revenue per room using ratios and proportions.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Hotel: 100 rooms, 75 occupied. Occupancy rate = 75/100 = 75%. Staff ratio: 1 staff per 5 guests, 150 guests = 150 ÷ 5 = 30 staff needed. Revenue per available room = Total revenue ÷ 100 rooms.
new_mappings.required_for: Performance tracking, staffing decisions, pricing strategy, profitability analysis

new_mappings.real_world_application: Drivers calculate fuel costs, trip distances, earnings, and vehicle efficiency using multiplication and division daily.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Taxi earnings: 20 trips × GHS 15 average = GHS 300 revenue. Fuel: 200km ÷ 12km/liter = 16.7 liters needed. Fuel cost: 16.7 × GHS 14/liter = GHS 234. Profit: 300 - 234 = GHS 66.
new_mappings.required_for: Income calculation, fuel budgeting, route planning, vehicle economics

new_mappings.real_world_application: Logistics is ALL math - calculating shipping costs, warehouse capacity, delivery schedules, and inventory turnover.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Warehouse: 50m × 40m × 4m high = 8,000 cubic meters. Boxes: 1m³ each, stack 3 high. Capacity: (50 × 40 ÷ 1) × 3 = 6,000 boxes. Truck holds 200 boxes, need 6,000 ÷ 200 = 30 truckloads.
new_mappings.required_for: Capacity planning, shipping calculations, inventory management, cost optimization

new_mappings.real_world_application: Solar technology converts light energy into electrical energy - understanding energy transformation is fundamental to solar installation.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Solar panel converts sunlight (light energy) → electrical energy in photovoltaic cells → stored in batteries (chemical energy) → powers home appliances (back to electrical, then light/heat/motion energy).
new_mappings.required_for: System design, efficiency calculations, troubleshooting, customer education

new_mappings.real_world_application: Solar technicians calculate panel output, battery capacity, energy consumption, and system sizing using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Home uses 300 watts for 8 hours = 300 × 8 = 2,400 watt-hours daily. Solar panel produces 100 watts × 5 sun hours = 500 watt-hours daily. Panels needed: 2,400 ÷ 500 = 5 panels minimum.
new_mappings.required_for: System sizing, cost estimation, energy audits, performance monitoring

new_mappings.real_world_application: Network engineers calculate bandwidth, data transfer rates, subnet sizes, and network capacity using multiplication and division.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Internet speed: 100 Mbps = 100 million bits per second. Downloading 500 MB file = 4,000 Mb (500 × 8). Time: 4,000 ÷ 100 = 40 seconds. Office with 50 users: 100 Mbps ÷ 50 = 2 Mbps per user.
new_mappings.required_for: Bandwidth planning, performance optimization, capacity management, troubleshooting

new_mappings.real_world_application: Cybersecurity involves calculating encryption strengths, analyzing attack patterns, and assessing risk probabilities - all using math.
new_mappings.example_scenario: Security analysis: System receives 10,000 login attempts per hour. Normal = 500/hour. Current rate = 10,000 ÷ 500 = 20× normal = potential attack. Password combinations: 8 characters, 26 letters = 26^8 = 208 billion combinations.
new_mappings.required_for: Threat analysis, risk assessment, security metrics, incident investigation
